description: social +‎ -ity, from French socialité or directly from Latin sociālitās (“fellowship, sociality”), from sociālis (“social”), from socius (“companion, ally”) + -ālis.

entries.meaning: The character of being social; sociability
The quality of an animal kind of being social.
(in the plural) Social events or entertainments; pleasantries.
examples: [A]fterwards he had no leisure for the game, and no inclination for the socialities there.
